What is the significance of the blue dots in the graph?
<image>
ground_truth: The blue dots in the graph represent the testing error ∆tx as a function of the entropy Hh of the fit signal h(t). The entropy Hh is a measure of the uncertainty in the fit signal, and the testing error ∆tx is a measure of the difference between the fit signal and the training signal. ground_truth: The graph is used to illustrate the results of the full set of enumerations on the 10 datasets to elicit the best value of the penalty parameter λ in the regularized ERM objective of LUN (θ) + λ‖θ‖2. The SGD algorithm is used to solve each instance of the regularized formulation in each of the 10 partitions of the dataset. A mini-batch size of 10 was used along with step size sequence γt = 0.25 ∗ (5000./(5000. + t)). The plots on the left provide the regularization enumeration for five datasets that achieved a best test misclassification error of 15% or higher, whereas the plots on the right provide the regularization enumeration for five datasets that achieved a best test misclassification error of 9% or lower. question:
<image>
What does the graph in Figure 1 show?
ground_truth:
The graph in Figure 1 shows the allocation rules for q̂ ex ante optimal pricings in Example 4, for a fixed type v. The graph is divided into two parts, with the left side representing the case where q̂ < 1 − F (B) = 1 − B, and the right side representing the case where q̂ > 1 − B.

In the left side, the graph shows that a lottery that costs B is offered, and when bought, it sells the item with probability π = B + q̂. A type with value at least B/(B + q̂) will buy the lottery (and hence wins with probability B + q̂).

In the right side, the graph shows that the budget does not bind and the item is sold at a price of 1 − q̂; all types with v ≥ 1 − q̂ wins the item with certainty.

This immediately shows us the shape of Gv(q̂), the probability of allocation as a function of q̂ for a fixed type v. From the perspective of a given type v ≥ B, Gv(q̂) jumps starts at q̂ = Bv −B, increases linearly with q̂ and saturates at q̂ = 1−B. This is depicted in Figure 1a. For v < B, the budget never binds, and the corresponding Gv(q̂) is the familiar step function (Figure 1b).
